etymologies: Old English; earliest use found in Glosses to Herbarium of Pseudo-Apuleius. Cognate with or formed similarly to Old Saxon hasalwurt (Middle Low German hāselwort), Old High German hasalwurz (Middle High German haselwurz, German Haselwurz), Swedish hasselört, Old Danish haselyrd (Danish hasselurt) from the Germanic base of hazel + the Germanic base of wort; probably so called on account of the resemblance of the calyx to the involucre of a hazelnut

definitions: Asarabacca, Asarum europaeum, which has purplish-brown flowers and petiolate leaves.
